quote: I told her that if she didn't remove them, I would.
And what changed your mind?
You did, colonel. Remind me never to play poker with you.
Well, Worf... did I not promise you a glorious battle?
It is all that I had hoped for.
EM pulse ready, general.
Then what are you waiting for? Fire!
By all means, Chief. Fire.
It's working.
Great. Now can we leave?
Full impulse.
I hope Jadzia appreciates all this...
I think she does.
Lohm-Ict-lihj posh-Machh-lodge Sto-vo-kor... (Open your gates, Sto-vo-kor... )

Jadzia pay-lodge pah-dock-Lih Dun. Shoo-vwee-vahm baht-leh pay- lodge. Pay-lodge Poh-Hokh-Vahd Sto-vo-kor. (Welcome Jadzia to your halls... welcome this honored warrior... welcome her, Sto-vo-kor, for all eternity.)
The Sisko has completed his task.
Sarah?
The Kosst Amojan no longer threatens us. All has been restored.
You mean the Pah-wraith? It's no longer in the wormhole?
I have cast it out.
Is that why the Prophets sent me to Tyree? To release you from the Orb?
The Kosst Amojan tried to stop you with a false vision. But you did not waver. You fulfilled your destiny.
My destiny? You make it sound like my life's over.
The Sisko must still face many tasks.
I don't suppose you're going to tell me what they are...
The Emissary is corporeal. Linear.
Linear or not, I need some answers.
The Sisko is intrusive.
Are you Sarah Sisko? Are you my mother?
Sarah Sisko was corporeal. For a time, I shared her existence.
You took over her body -- (putting it all together) -- made sure she married my father... so that she'd give birth to me...
The Sisko is necessary.
And once you didn't need her anymore, you left her... no wonder she walked out on my father. She never chose him, you did.
The Sisko would prefer different answers.
What you're telling me isn't easy to accept... you arranged my birth. I exist because of you.
The Sisko's path is a difficult one.
But why me? Why did it have to be me?
Because it could be no one else.
Benjamin?
That must've been some Orb experience.
I'll tell you about it... someday.
Welcome back, captain.
We've missed you, sir.
Thank you -- I knew you'd bring the Prophets back to us.
I hear you've all been pretty busy yourselves.
Nerys! Julian! Odo! It's so good to see you. Worf -- we need to talk --!
Who's that?
That's Dax.
Dax?
That's right, Ezri Dax. Incredible, isn't it?
It cannot be...
She's so much... shorter.
Just when you thought things couldn't get more interesting...
I am merely a businessman. It would take an orator with the skills of the late, great Plegg himself, to sing the praises of the late, great Plegg.

What Ferengi could resist the honor of owning a small piece of the man who took a computer chip and turned it into the modular holosuite industry... a small piece of the man who brought holographic entertainment to the most remote parts of this quadrant, creating profit centers from societies that could barely afford to feed their own people...
How much are you asking?
As I was about to tell my good friend here, a mere three strips of latinum...
And I'd be taking a loss at that price... okay, for you, two strips... (sighs, he's lost him, to odo) Thank you very much.
Three strips? That's a fair price for Plegg.
I suppose you're interested.
Humanoid death rituals are an interest of mine.
Death rituals.
Everybody needs a hobby.
Uh huh...

Some species burn their dead, others pack them in blocks of ice... some even surround themselves with the company of family corpses. But the Ferengi ritual of chopping up their loved ones and selling them... I find that... irresistible.
I'm very busy here.
What a fitting and dignified way to honor the memory of great Ferengi entrepreneurs. I'm thinking of starting a collection.
Putting up a display case in my office. There'll be a special space reserved for you in there, Quark.
I'm sure.
You're serious?
Have you ever known me not to be?
Oh, there is one thing I was curious about...
(knows something's coming) And what's that...
How do I know it's Plegg?
It says so on the label.
Isn't there some sort of letter of authenticity?
The Ferengi Seal of Dismemberment is right there. What more do you want?
I want Plegg.
You've got him!
Not if he's still alive...
Still alive?
Still alive.
Plegg?
When I tracked him down on Khosla Two and told him about your little scheme, he was quite amused. I'm not.
Odo, I'm a victim here. I bought these discs in good faith. I have five thousand pieces of Plegg in my storeroom.
Not Plegg.
Then who?
Good question.
I demand an investigation...
You'll get one. I promise you.
Odo...
Doctor Mora...
It's been too long.
You're looking well. Yes, coming along nicely.
Why didn't you let me know you were coming?
It was a last minute arrangement.
The trip from Bajor takes five hours.
Ah, can I get you something... Doctor "Mora" was it?
Yes. Some Deka tea would be nice...
You haven't quite managed the ears, yet, have you? But, they're difficult. Is the suit a suit, or part of you? And what about the boots?
There we are... nice and hot...
Thank you...
So... You two seem to be old friends...
Doctor Mora is the Bajoran scientist who was assigned to me after I was found.
I was personally responsible for his development during his formative years.
Then, this is a family reunion! I had a hunch... well, Odo's dad is always welcome in Quark's... the tea is on the house...
I know he wouldn't tell you himself. But Odo is doing a wonderful job here on the station if I may say so...
Is he...
Absolutely. As a matter of fact, when you came in, he was just beginning a fraud investiga...
Quark! Excuse us.
Of course. You two have a lot of catching up to do. If there's anything I can help you with, Doctor, don't hesitate to call on me.
That was uncalled for.
You don't know Quark.
I know he was trying very hard to present you in a positive light to someone he thought was important to you and you responded with...
("don't lecture me" implied) Please...
Still having trouble with social integration... ?
I integrate as much as I want to.
Define "as much as I want to."
"As much as I want to" means as much as I want to. (already tired of this, a last defense)
So how is this police thing you got yourself into working out?
I enjoy my work as chief of security.
(casual, not realizing the pain this causes) "Chief of security." At a weigh station in space.
Don't you miss it, Odo?
What.
Our work.
Never.

I don't believe it. I know you too well. You were unhappy in the lab. I couldn't blame you for that. But the work, Odo. The exploration of you. What you are. Where you came from. That's never far from your mind, is it. Tell me the truth.
That part of it... is true.
Good. Because I came here counting on that.
See you later, Dad...
Hey... hey... hold on...
I'm late...
For what?
For Nog.
Your homework...
It's done...
You've studied that whole Klingon opera for your music test Friday?...
I'm gonna ace the test, Dad, I promise...
That isn't what I asked...
It's not until Friday...
This isn't about tests, Jake. This is about learning.
You can't learn to appreciate Klingon opera by just cramming the night before an exam.
I'm never gonna learn to appreciate Klingon opera. It's a waste of time.
Being with Nog is not a waste of time but Klingon opera is?
Yeah! What am I ever going to use Klingon opera for?
First of all, you don't know what you'll be when you grow up... you may discover along the way you want to be a musician or you may wind up around Klingons in some job somewhere...
Dad, even if I do, they won't be going around singing operas...
It helps to understand their culture...
When was the last time you listened to a Klingon opera?
(beat, knowing that he's getting sucked in) When I was your age.
There, you see?
Yes. Do you?
Dad, just because you had to suffer through all that doesn't mean I have to.
Yes. It does.
Come in...
Dad...
Nog has the same test. Why don't you invite him over to listen to the Klingon opera together?
Sit down, Odo.
Commander, I'd like to request the use of a runabout.
Of course. What's up?
Doctor Mora Pol from the Bajoran Institute of Science asked me to help him secure one from the Federation.
Why did he come to you?

Doctor Mora was the scientist who was assigned to me in my first years here... if he went to the Board of Ministers to request permission to approach you, it would take months. And he's very anxious to investigate something in the Gamma Quadrant. And may I say, Commander, so am I.
You've got me curious, Constable. Is it a secret?

No, but there isn't much to tell. One of the Bajoran science probes recently scanned a planet about six light years from the wormhole. It picked up some very unique and familiar DNA patterns. Patterns very much like my own, Commander. Doctor Mora thinks he may have found the origin of my people... of... me...

As a scientist yourself, Lieutenant, you can appreciate the difficulty of our dilemma, and the elegance of the solution. When Odo was first found, no one knew who, or indeed, what we were dealing with.
A shapeless, viscous mass of fluid, a veritable organic broth. That was our Odo in the beginning.
When did you realize you were dealing with a sentient lifeform?
He didn't. I had to teach him that myself.
That's true. That's very true. Tell her.
It was a dilemma for me. I'd never seen anything like these creatures either.
"Seen" isn't really an appropriate description. He had no eyes per se...
I was only trying to describe it in simple terms...
He had never perceived anything like us before... go on...
And I knew I had to find some way to communicate with them. So I transformed myself into...

(taking the story away) It was remarkable. I'd been coming into the lab every morning, and every morning Odo was still in his liquid form, resting in a Krokan petri beaker. Well... one morning, Odo wasn't there. The beaker was empty, and beside it: an identical beaker that had not been there before.
A perfect replica in every way. It was amazing. It hasn't been the same since you left, Odo. Working with you was the most rewarding part of my career.
We're approaching the planet.
Preparing to enter standard orbit... planet designated L-S-Six.
Initiating scans.
There's a lot of seismic activity down there... possibly volcanic in origin...
That's consistent with the probe's analysis of the area...
Perhaps that's why the changelings had to leave this world...
"Changelings?" That's a new one.
I've met people from the Gamma quadrant who've heard stories of a lifeform...
(laughs, interrupting, victorious) And you said you weren't interested in our work anymore...
That's not what I said...
I think I've located the area where the probe identified the trace elements... I'm picking up the same DNA traces... entering coordinates...
Moving into synchronous orbit.
Look at these readings, Doctor... I believe there's some kind of artificial structure on the surface...
(smiles, in anticipation) Is it safe to go down, Lieutenant?
Surface disturbances are minor... for the moment anyway...
Let's do it.
Do the letters mean anything to you?
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: No. I don't think so.
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Well, judging by its position in the ruins, I think it's fair to say this pillar represented something important to the people who lived here.
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Why don't we take it with us... our computer back on the station might be able to decipher the inscription...
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Where's Doctor Weld gone to? Weld?
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Over here.
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: I may have found what we're looking for.
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Is it carbon based?
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: No. Silicate, but vegetative, and very much alive.
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Odo Junior, perhaps?
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Computer, begin transport.
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Computer, realign transporter... lock on to our combadges...
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Stand by...
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Ready for transport...
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Computer, energize!
scene: 8    EXT. PLANET SURFACE - AMID THE RUINS (OPTICAL)

quote: Deep Space Nine... this is the Rio Grande. I have seriously injured personnel on board. Request emergency action.
(on communicator to Odo) We read you, Odo. Who's injured?
Dax, Doctor Mora, and Doctor Weld. There was some kind of volcanic gas...
When you get within transporter range, I'll beam them directly to the Infirmary.
Alert Doctor Bashir.

They're stable for now. Dax is in fair condition, the Bajorans seem to be more seriously affected. Perhaps they were exposed to more of the gas, or there may be something about Trill physiology... I'm not sure yet...
And Odo?
I'm fine.
The paralyzing action occurred when the gas was taken into the respiratory system. Since Odo doesn't have a respiratory system as we know it, he apparently wasn't affected at all.

O'Brien's off-loaded the cargo they brought back. He's set up everything in the Science Lab. I understand there are some organic specimens from that planet. Maybe there's something that can help you figure this out.
Good idea.
Will he be all right?
The molecule appears to have quite an unstable structure. That might mean the effect is temporary.
I know how you feel, Constable.
Feel? About what?

When my father got ill... I remember thinking how small and weak he looked lying there in the bed. He'd been so strong... independent... to me it always seemed there was nothing he couldn't do. In the end, I realized that there was nothing he could do. And nothing I could do to help him.
I appreciate your thoughts, Commander. But Doctor Mora is not my father.
Kak-lah... Kak-lah... Kah-pool-AYYY- do-la-kak-lah... Yoh boo la to dah... Yoh boo la to da...
The computer's having a hard time classifying your new lifeform.
Why?
Whatever it is keeps changing... somehow it goes through a metamorphosis every time it reproduces... and it reproduces like crazy. Look at this...
It's multiplied so much, I had to change containers... I'll put it in a level-five security field overnight. I wish Dax were here to take a look at it... how's she doing... ?
Doctor Bashir thinks she'll be fine...
Have any idea what it is?
I'm hoping it's a key, Mister O'Brien. A key to my past.
Kira to Sisko.
Go ahead, Major...
Sorry to bother you, Commander. But we need you up here in the Science Lab.
I'm on my way.
Any signs of a break-in?
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: Not that we've been able to find... the security seal on the lab was still in place when we got here...
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: I can't imagine why anyone would want to steal that thing anyway...
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: You're suggesting the lifeform itself did this...
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: I don't know what did this. Commander. Unless a tornado passed this way without us hearing it. The room was locked. It's gone... that's all I know for now.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: Let's go to yellow alert. Get a Level Three Security Scan of the entire station underway.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: Our scanners are probably gonna have trouble finding this lifeform.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: It has metamorphic qualities that were confusing the computer. You better run the sweep two or three times.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: Major, you could help me by reviewing the security camera records and the heat sensor readouts for the Lab and the surrounding areas.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: Commander, I'm picking up slight trace elements near the ventilation intake duct. It looks as though the lifeform may have taken this way out.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: Doctor Bashir give you permission to be up and about?
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: (as she moves, examining the damage) "Doctor Bashir" wouldn't listen to me and hid my clothes so I wouldn't leave.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: I had to sneak out to my quarters in a hospital gown that wouldn't close in the back... but I met a nice ensign on the way. What did this...
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: The working theory is that the lifeform you brought back is somehow responsible...
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: I don't believe it.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: Good. Find me a better theory.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: Odo, Doctor Mora is awake and wants to see you.
scene: 33   INT. SCIENCE LAB - MOMENTS AFTER PREVIOUS SCENE

quote: I heard them say something had happened in the lab.
The lifeform sample is gone.
Gone?
We're not sure why or how yet...
I want to help...
Everything is under control...
I know more about shape-shifters than anyone in this sector...
Anyone except me, and I'll be running the investigation.
Besides we're not even sure it is a shape-shifting lifeform...
Any metamorphic characteristics?
It was changing faster than the computer could analyze.
Any indication of intelligence...
Not unless you consider wanton destruction of the lab an indication of intelligence...
It might be... It might be... Don't dismiss any possibility...
Doctor Weld hasn't regained consciousness. I feel... responsible.
I know Doctor Bashir is doing everything possible.
The same trace elements are inside the duct...
I'm following the trail, moving toward Corridor Two-H...
Nothing's showing up anywhere on the scanners, Chief.
Yeah, I figured as much. Did the security cameras in the lab give you anything?
The security cameras stopped operating for forty-three seconds at zero-three hundred hours, five minutes... right when the alarm sounded...
Stopped... you mean somebody turned them off?
More likely some kind of power interruption... It might have affected the security field around the lifeform too... We're trying to analyze it now...
Do the heat sensors in the lab show any thermal deviation at the same time?
Almost a six degree increase during the forty-three seconds...
But then back to normal after that.
Affirmative.
We might be dealing with an entity that absorbs low frequency R-F energy... it might be feeding off our power...
But an energy drain should be showing up on our scans...
Yeah, that's true, Constable. I don't get it. Maybe this thermal deviation was the result of...
Chief?
Hold on, I hear something.
We've got your position. Nothing else is showing up anywhere near you...
Well, I definitely hear something ahead... can you hear it on the comm line... ?
No...
It almost sounds like... I don't know how to describe it... I'm moving in closer... If you run into my wife, don't mention I did this...
Move some backup to the nearest corridor...
(acknowledges, hits combadge) Security to Core Section, Level Four, Corridor Two-H...
I'll come home tonight and she'll ask me how my day was... and I'll say, fine, honey, how was yours?...
Sometimes I think she really doesn't want to know the truth, so I do us both a favor and...
Just a structural breach... we need to get a maintenance crew up here...
Shouldn't be any problem to...
Ahhh!
O'Brien report!
I'm okay... I'm fine... I found our missing lifeform...
Except it's not a lifeform anymore. It's dead.

Station log, Stardate 47391.7. Engineering crews have been working for over fifteen hours searching conduits throughout the core section. There have been no additional incidents and no further evidence of the alien lifeform has been found. Yellow alert has been canceled.
With this kind of cellular structure, the lifeform would have needed a higher concentration of carbon dioxide than our atmosphere provides...
It just couldn't survive out of its own environment.
That'd be my analysis...
But with that in mind, do you still think this lifeform was capable of destroying the lab?
It's not impossible. The environmental impact might have taken some time to set in.
I really would like Doctor Mora's opinion on all this...
He's a lot better. He should be up and around in the morning.
Feel like a Raktajino before we call it a night?
My replicator or yours...
I was thinking of the Promenade.
I knew that. Thanks anyway. I have a few things to wrap up here.
Sleep tight, Julian.
She enjoys it... it gives her some perverse kind of pleasure. One of these days, I'll stop chasing her and then we'll see...
as he wonders to himself what the noise might have been, we see a vague figure drop silently from the ceiling behind him... Bashir doesn't react...
Emergency! Emergency! Intruder alert.
It happened so quickly. I'm sorry I can't tell you more about it. It was behind me, then it was gone. But it was big. Very big.
How badly did you injure it?
I don't know. I don't know if I injured it at all. I just hit it once with a laser scalpel on its arm, or leg, or tentacle... whatever it was, and it moved up the wall and... was gone.
(with scientific distance) It appears our lifeform has survived and grown into something interesting.
Did you notice anything else about the room when you entered, Doctor... anything out of place, anything unusual... (Bashir shakes his head, doesn't think so) Was it unusually warm, perhaps?
Now that you mention it, it was a bit warm in here...
Another thermal distortion... Did you try the lights, Doctor?
No, I didn't want to disturb the patients.
Commander, I suggest we check the R- F energy flow to the Infirmary... we might find a power interruption just as we did in the lab.
No blood, or any fluid traces. But I am picking up a very slight trail of something we didn't see last time. An organic residue.
Enough to test?
We'll see.
Sisko to Ops.KIRA'S COM VOICE Go ahead.
Restrict all nonessential personnel to their quarters and go to red alert, Major.
Understood.
Keep in touch with Dax's progress... she might give us a way to track this thing...
Until we can, I suggest we close down the Promenade.
I'll give the order, Constable.
"Constable."
It's a nickname that I barely tolerate.
It's the expression of affection that you find uncomfortable.
You know, that was really a remarkable display back there...
Display?
You were careful, attentive...
I was just doing my job.
Yes, well, I'm beginning to think that the scientific method and the police method have a lot in common.
I never thought of it that way. Perhaps they do.

In science we look for the obvious. We track in straight lines. If something looks too good to be true, it probably isn't true. If there seems to be more to something than meets the eye, there usually is more. We take it step by step.
That would apply to criminal investigation also.
You do it very well. I'm proud of you, Odo. Did you know that?
Anything?
The computer's having trouble breaking down the DNA chains.
What about the pillar... has the computer had any success decoding the encryption?
No luck there either. All things considered, the computer's having a bad week. We have such a limited database for the Gamma Quadrant...
I have to shut down the Promenade... call me when you have something...
Wasn't that pillar over there before?
(without looking up from her work) I had to have it moved. It was in my way.
Have you compared this new organic sample to the lifeform we brought back from the planet... ?
Only enough to be sure that it's not the same...
It might be interesting to see if there are any commonalties at all.
Let me run a cross-tabulation analysis... it should only take a couple of minutes...
Do you know Odo well, Lieutenant?
Not as well as I'd like to. He... keeps to himself a lot.
I'm not surprised. I didn't realize... until I actually saw him... ... how much I missed him... we didn't part on very good terms...
So I've heard.

I didn't want him to leave. We still had so much work to do... (not entirely convinced of what he's saying) But I see him now and I wonder if he wasn't right to go after all... he's come such a long way...
He's an invaluable man around here.

I never thought he could do it. Integrate successfully. If you could have seen him back then, how ill- prepared he was to be on his own... I was so sure he'd come back. When he left, I told him he'd come back... And all these years, I was still certain that eventually, he'd show up one day at the lab... I guess I'd better get used to the idea that he's not going to.
Here we are...
Which one is this?
That's the new one from the Infirmary. This is the lifeform from the planet... but remember it went through several metamorphoses...
No, it's not the same entity... the nucleotide sequences are entirely different...
Some metachromic similarities...
Yes... on the most basic level... it may be a distant cousin at best...
The computer's broken down the DNA chain on the new sample.
I can run an analysis to see if it matches up with any other lifeform in the computer...
How long will that take?
Two, three hours, maybe.
Let me know.
Doctor Weld has regained consciousness. It looks like he'll be fine.
That's a relief.
You don't seem relieved.
(appreciating him anew) You can tell that just by observing me, can't you... the tone of my voice, my eyes, my body movements...
Yes.
You are such a remarkable lifeform, Odo. But there is so much we still don't understand about you.
What are you getting at, Doctor... ?

The computer has broken down the DNA chain of the organic sample we found in the Infirmary. Dax is running an analysis of it now. She'll have it identified in a couple of hours. But I already know what it is. I've seen it before. The organic sample... it's from you, Odo.

The destruction in the Science Lab occurred at zero-three hundred hours, five minutes. Then the attack in the Infirmary occurred at nineteen- thirty-five. Roughly sixteen hours apart. Is your rejuvenation period still sixteen hours...
I was in my pail during both attacks.
But were you... I don't think so. I think, Odo, that you have been in the rather ironic position of trying to track down... yourself.
How could this be?
Has anything like this happened before?
Of course not.
Are you certain?
Of course, I'm certain. There would have been incidents.
No unsolved crimes on the books?
There are always unsolved crimes.
Then, the possibility exists...
It doesn't. I do not commit criminal acts. It is not in my nature.
(the evidence before us) Isn't it?
The gas. Maybe it was the gas on the planet. It must have affected me in some way.
A possibility.
That has to be it.
It's certainly worth investigating.
Doctor Bashir might be able to...

Doctor Bashir won't be able to understand anything about this... except that you turned into some kind of out-of-control thing that almost killed him. Really, Odo. What do you think they'll do with you?
Do?
They won't know what to do. They'll put you in some kind of high security prison, or quarantine you on a deserted asteroid in the Gamma Quadrant. Odo, they'll put you in a zoo.
I don't believe that. You don't know them...
What other humanoid have you ever been able to trust except me?
What makes you think I trust you...

I resent that. I really do. After the time I invested in you. The education I gave you. The attention I gave you. You wouldn't be here today without my guidance. I gave you more than anyone else in my life. You were my life. And you walked away. Now, you don't trust me? Fine, put yourself in their hands then. Always had to learn your lessons the hard way, didn't you...
I am not going back to the center with you...
Why? We'll work through this together. The two of us.
We'll solve it together. Just as we used to.
No.
Commander, I've got a power failure in Security...
Sisko to Odo... Sisko to Odo.
All deputies report to Security Office... possible intruder.
I'm tracking it...

We have a power drain in the life support conduit above the Security Office. If it's feeding off our power, we might be able to slow it down by shutting off the primary flow to the entire core section...
Do it.
Where the hell did it come from?
And where's Odo...
Go ahead.
No sign of Odo?
Nossir.
I can help you with that, Major.
The creature you're after is Odo. There must have been... some kind of metamorphic reaction to the volcanic gas we encountered on the planet.
Is there any way to communicate with him?
I don't know. It's not Odo really... it's separate and independent from the Odo we know... and yet... At the very least, it is aware... of me.
How can you know that?

The incident in the Science Lab... I think it was an attempt to "rescue" the lifeform I put into containment... the second encounter was in the Infirmary where I was sleeping... the third took place minutes ago when we were having a... heated discussion in Security. I think your... "Constable" himself would draw the same conclusion from the evidence... on some instinctual level, this creature is familiar with me.
He might even conclude it has hostile intentions toward you.
That has occurred to me.
The power shutdown is complete, Commander. Odo... or whatever it is... has stopped moving for the moment.
Chief, based on your knowledge of its behavior, if we can lure him out, is there any way to set up a forcefield that can hold him...
We could reverse polarity on the energy fields and it might work... but that's only a guess.
Set it up on the Promenade... I want a lot of room to operate... Major, station security teams along the perimeter...
How do we get him to come out of the conduits?
Maybe we can use some R-F energy bursts to attract him...
I think there's only one thing that's going to attract that creature into your trap. It's me he's after.
Mister O'Brien?
Our plan seems to be working, Commander. It's following my trail of energy crumbs right toward you...
On my signal, open the conduit and let him in...
Aye, sir...

We can't be sure which vent he'll come through. Hopefully, it'll be the first one available to him... ... over there... but if not, there are seventeen others he might choose. We're not stationing officers near any of them... we don't want to scare him away.
I understand.
Just get him to the forcefield. We'll do the rest.

Pass the word that phasers are to be set on maximum stun... the moment Doctor Mora appears to be in jeopardy, I'll open fire. Their orders are to follow my lead. If maximum stun doesn't bring him down immediately, we set phasers to kill.
Commander...
I know, Major. Those are the orders.
Mister O'Brien, we're ready.
Releasing the conduit seal.
Doctor Mora, did you hear that?
Ready and waiting.
What are you waiting for? I'm here. And I'm not going anywhere.
I've done it to you again, haven't I, Odo. Made you a prisoner. Dear God, what have I done.
Mister O'Brien, drop the field.
Aye, sir.
We have a lot to talk about.

I'm not going to try to explain exactly what happened to you, Odo... because I haven't the vaguest idea... I can tell you with Doctor Mora's help we've managed to eliminate all traces of the gas from your cellular structure... I'll prescribe rest because it's hard for a doctor to go wrong with that one... but otherwise, there's not much more I can do for you.
Thank you, Doctor.
I'm going home.
Doctor Mora, I want to be sure you know that I had no idea...
You had to speak in a voice loud enough for me to hear.
I'm... sorry.
I'm sorry it was necessary. I would like... in a small way... to be a part of your life again... your life on the station. From time to time, we could talk. About things that matter to you. To us.
I'd... like that.

Medical log, Stardate 47229.1. Chief O'BRIEN and I have been working overtime to prepare for the arrival of a new cartographer. Ensign Melora Pazlar is the first Elaysian to join Starfleet and, as such, requires special accommodations.
and I have been working overtime to prepare for the arrival of a new cartographer. Ensign Melora Pazlar is the first Elaysian to join Starfleet and, as such, requires special accommodations.
I haven't seen one of these in three hundred years.
I'm surprised it was even on file in the replicator's data bank.
It wasn't. Ensign Pazlar sent me the specifications.
She actually uses one like this?
Her normal anti-grav unit isn't going to work here... same problem we had with the Starfleet cargo lifts... Cardassian construction just isn't compatible.
On our way.
Think of what she's gone through to get here, Jadzia... what it must be like to adjust to our gravity after growing up on a planet with low surface gravity.
Doctor... !
We've done the best we can with the ramps... the Cardassians obviously didn't have her in mind when they built the place...
I've managed to modify the maximum vertical clearance of the chair three centimeters to a slope of fifty-six degrees.
That still leaves a lot of places around here she won't have access to...
Can't we just use the transporter to help her get around?
Makes sense to me, but she sent word that it wouldn't be acceptable to her.
I wonder why...
I know exactly why... she went through the Academy the same way. Once her basic needs were met, she refused any special attention. She's extraordinary.
You make it sound like you've known her for years...
I almost feel that way... I've pulled all her personnel and medical files to get ready... Her quarters... they're ready, aren't they?
I have the bumps on my head to prove it.
Thanks, Chief.
Let me know if there's anything else I can do.
That'll be something to see... when we turn off the gravity and she flies around her room...
Ensign Melora Pazlar reporting for duty.
Welcome to DS Nine, Ensign. I'm Chief Science Officer, Jadzia Dax... and this...
Doctor Bashir... we spoke on subspace...
Good to meet you in person...
I see you have my trolley car ready to go...
As requested.
Here, let me help...
I'm fine, thank you.
That's better.
You've modified it.
I wanted to give you as much mobility as I could.
I've been practicing on the model I requested for a month...
It's... really no problem... I can replicate the other design...
No, I'll just have to adapt.
I really don't think that'll be necessary, Lieutenant... I'm perfectly capable of piloting a runabout...
Commander Sisko thought...
I'm sure he thought what every officer I've served with has thought... that I need extra help to get the job done. Please tell him, I don't.
I'm sure the Chief Science Officer has more important things to do than to chart a sector in the Gamma Quadrant...
Here we are...
You haven't modified the specifications I gave you for my quarters, I hope...
Not one iota. You can control the gravity unit with this device. If you'd like to try it out...
Thank you, I will. It's been a pleasure meeting both of you.
Paltriss only created eighty of them... each a work of art...
And I've come into possession of forty-two.
Forty-two? My world will honor your name for returning the Rings of Paltriss to his birthplace...
(drops ring in pouch, puts pouch in pocket) Honor my name all you want... as long as your honor is accompanied by one hundred and ninety-nine bars of gold-pressed latinum...
I've heard that you drive a hard bargain...
Shall we celebrate our closing the deal with another drink... ?
Excuse me, I'm sorry but we're not open yet... if you'll come back in...
(now nervous, to Ashrock) Have another drink on me.
Fallit... Fallit Kot... is that really you? How long has it been?
Eight years. Eight long years.
It can't be... I must say, you look terrific... tanned... toned up... all of that baby fat has disappeared from your face...
You don't keep extra weight on, where I've been...
Just passing through, are you? I'll bet you have business in the Gamma Quadrant... you always had a sharp eye for fresh territory...
I'm not going to the Gamma Quadrant. My business is right here. With you.
With me?
That's right. (leans in; no brag, just fact) I've come to kill you, Quark.
I've gone through her mission profile. She certainly knows what she's doing...
Nevertheless, this is her first deep space assignment... and it doesn't make sense to me to... (rising, interrupting himself) Here she is...
Ensign, I'm Commander Benjamin Sisko...
Am I late?
Not at all.
It looked like the meeting had already begun.
Dax and Bashir were just telling me about your request to pilot a runabout alone.
Wouldn't it have been appropriate to include me in that conversation?
I was getting a briefing by my senior officers, Ensign. We talk about personnel matters all the time.
I'm sorry if I seem overly sensitive. But I'm used to being shut out of the "Melora" problem. The truth is there is no "Melora" problem. Until people create one.
This may sound ungrateful, because Doctor Bashir has been wonderfully helpful in the preparations for my arrival, but frankly, I wonder why a medical opinion is necessary in this discussion.
Julian knows more about your capabilities than any of us.
I don't need a medical opinion to tell me my own capabilities...
I also know the station and the runabouts...
I've studied the station's schematics... and I've flown runabouts...
Ensign...
I simply object to being treated like someone who is ill.
I don't see anybody doing that.
Try sitting in the chair, Commander. No one can understand until they sit in the chair.

I've been in one chair or another since I left my homeworld. My family gave me this cane made from the wood of a garlanic tree. (chuckles at the naivete) ... they had no idea what it would be like to live off-world... in what you consider "normal" gravity. Only a handful of Elaysians have ever left home. But I always knew I had to be one of them.
I dreamed about exploring the stars as a girl. And I wasn't going to allow any... "handicap," not a chair, not a Cardassian station... to stop me from chasing that dream.
You must feel a great deal of pride in what you've been able to achieve.
And I've achieved it without being dependent on anybody. To be honest, I prefer working alone. It's simply easier for me.
I'm not comfortable sending you alone into the Gamma Quadrant.
Sir, I can focus on the job better, I can work at my own pace without bothering anyone else...
Lieutenant Dax will be going with you.
Yes sir. When do you wish to leave, Lieutenant?
Your schedule is fine with me.
Come in.
Is it working? The low-grav field actuator... I just heard it go off.
It's working fine.
So you were just...
For me, it's like slipping into a hot tub at the end of a long day.
Really. (because he can't ask what he wants to ask) I'm... a shower man, myself.
Look at this. Is that your husband... ? Boyfriend... ?
If you came for an apology, Doctor, I apologize.
Apology?
My speech was not intended to attack you personally.
I'm sure you never set out to attack anyone personally. But you do seem... to attack a lot.
That's rather insensitive of you, Doctor.
Julian. I'm no longer your doctor.
I see. You've decided I need a friend.
Was that an attack? You do it so well, with such charm, it's hard to tell.
I really don't mean to...
Sure you do.
I beg your pardon?
Always seemed to work pretty well. Until now.
That's the nicest thing you've said to me. Or anybody else for that matter. Are you hungry? I came here thinking about asking you to dinner.
Then afterward, we'll go dancing, I suppose.
Red alert.
Sorry.
Come on... there's a new Klingon restaurant on the Promenade... if you like that sort of thing.
All right.
Dinner is served.
I didn't order dinner.
What better way to mollify -- I mean, satisfy -- a hungry traveler than with a delicious home-cooked meal... starting with a delicate Vak clover soup...
Why spoil your appetite with soup?
Here's the real treat... Jumbo Vulcan mollusks.
Sauteed in rhombolian butter... a taste so exquisite, it's to die for... (realizes what he's just said) ... or to live for, for that matter...
Do you know dabo, Fallit?
A wonderfully entertaining game and easy to learn. I took the liberty of lining up a couple of excellent tutors I happen to know...

Be sure to ask them about their "double down" betting strategy. If I haven't made it clear, I intend to make your stay here as delightful as you could ever imagine. So allow me to propose a toast... to... Old friends.
Old debts.
Gruffs at Bashir to order --
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Gagh Tek Or!
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Shall I order for us both?
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: All right.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Let's see... we'll have some racht of course...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Racht...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: And a double order of Gladst... no sauce please...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Gladst... usu bal.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: And, a side order of zilm'kach... is that too much for two people... ?
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Drak doo.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: May I? As Bashir holds it down...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Don't be alarmed.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Excuse me, Julian, I can't eat this.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: I know how it looks but...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: P'kar tel Durg Le Frakn'l? (You call this live?)
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Dug a bul, rah'tar! (What's your problem, lady?)
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: D'tel klop a bul! (This slop you call food is the problem!
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Pak't pol! (If you don't like it, don't eat it!)
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: D'kar tel G'denna! (I want to see the blood running through the veins!)
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: I like a customer who knows what she wants...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Eh?
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: G'denna.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: There's nothing worse then half dead Racht.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: I was ten. My father was a Federation diplomat on Invernia Two. One day we were out on a remote part of the planet when a massive ionic storm hit. While we were waiting it out, we found an Invernian girl about my age who was sick. As soon as the storm cleared, my father went for help but it was too late. I sat there... and watched her die. The next day when my father returned, his guide told us we could have treated her with a simple herb that was growing all around us.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: I could have saved her life.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: And so you started to study medicine.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Yes... well, actually, first I started to study tennis.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Tennis?
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: I really thought about making a career of it for awhile...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: You must be very good...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: I used to think so, then I went to my first major competition... my opponent served first and I heard it bounce past me and the computer announced it was good and I knew I was in trouble... it turned out I had a bit more talent at medicine than tennis...
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: This has been delightful. Thank you.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: I'll never look at a Racht the same way again.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: I have an early mission tomorrow. I better get some rest.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Of course. Come on, I'll take you home.
scene: 18   INT. PROMENADE - KLINGON KIOSK - CLOSE ON A

quote: Dax to Pazlar. Computer, level one security access...
Ensign Pazlar?
Computer, locate Ensign Melora Pazlar.
Docking Level Twenty-Two, Section Fourteen.
Section Fourteen?
We've got to get you to the Infirmary...

(breathing heavily, agonizing) It's my own fault... I decided... I could use an extra astrometric array after going through the mission profile again... I came to the storage bay to get one... my mind was already in the Gamma Quadrant... I wasn't... paying enough attention to what I was doing... I guess my boot... didn't make the lip of the door... I fell on my controls...
Dax to Bashir. Ensign Pazlar's had a minor accident. We need to see you in the Infirmary.
Acknowledged. I'll be there in three minutes.
What kind... of architect would deliberately... design a raised rim at the entrance to every door...
So much for the dangers of the Gamma Quadrant... I didn't even make it there...
You will. There's no concussion... you can reschedule your mission for tomorrow...
It was so... (sighs, "humiliating" is implied) ... flopping back and forth... like a broken toy... I didn't want anyone to find me like that... but I couldn't get up by myself...
Why didn't you wait for Dax before you went into an area that wasn't modified with ramps...
I didn't need Dax... if I'd just paid attention...
Melora... no one on this station is completely independent... in space, we all depend on one another to some degree...
I just want you all to know you can depend on me...
Okay, you've proven that... what do the rest of us have to do to convince you?
Of what?
That you can depend on us.
Have you ever heard of the work Nathaniel Teros did with low gravity species thirty years ago?
Neuromuscular adaptation? It had no practical success at all.
No, but the principles were sound... and a lot of progress has been made in neurochemistry since then...
You think some day I could throw away the chair... ?
Theoretically... perhaps...
Would you like to come in... ?
I know how much you look forward to turning down the gravity...
Don't let that stop you...
You may want to brace yourself until you get used to it...
Come on, Julian.
What do I do?
Just give a gentle push... it's easy.
This is astonishing.
I can't tell you how curious I was about this...
Most people are. Sometimes they make me feel like a carnival attraction. So, usually, I prefer to keep everyone out...
Thank you... for letting me in.
He's my brother.
Oh.
Setting course... twenty-eight mark one-forty-two.
Computer, play us something by Delvok.
Delvok never seems Vulcan to me... there's too much emotion in his music...
It's pretty.
Tell me something, Lieutenant... you think there's room for... romance... in Starfleet?
I think so.
You've made it work... ?
Now and then...
I mean, really work...
Oh, really work. For that, I've got to go back... (beat, smiling at the memory) ... about a hundred and fifty years.
That's a long time...
She was a hard act to follow.
Could it be Doctor Bashir's bedside manner has won you over... ?
Our species are just so... different.
Since when has that ever stopped anybody?... I knew a hydrogen-breathing Lothra who fell hopelessly in love with an Oxygene...
You're kidding... how could they even stay in the same room?
Forty minutes a day without their breathing apparatus... that's all. Lovely couple... fifty-seven years they were together.
What about career conflicts? Two friends of mine from the Academy got engaged even though they knew they were assigned to different starships...
Subspace relationship?
Uh huh.
That's a tough one.
They may not be together for a year or more... and even then only for a few weeks...
Love across light years is just so...
... it lacks intimacy...
... you could say that.
I finish my mission here... I move on to the next one... what kind of future is that for a romance?
Look at the alternative.
I guess...
Maybe it's better not to look to the future... just look to tonight.
I guess...
Smile, Ensign, you're in love.
Oh. It's you.
Don't be so happy to see me...
All right, I won't.
Odo, there's a desperate criminal on board the station...
You wouldn't be talking about Fallit
... who just finished eight years in a labor camp for hijacking a shipment of Romulan ale. (stops working, turns to Quark) ... whose name was right next to yours on the original indictment... ?
I had nothing to do with the hijacking itself. I was... only the middleman...
Trafficking in stolen goods should have been enough to get you your own cell at that Romulan camp... unless you sold out your partner...
I can honestly say that justice was served.
I would imagine that Fallit Kot is looking for his own kind of justice now.
He's threatened to kill me.
What?! ("are you looking at" implied) Odo resumes his usual stern expression, sighs...
Nothing. Just a passing thought...
Odo, he means it. Nothing I do seems to change his mind. You've got to do something.
I'll do my job, Quark.
Unfortunately...
Racht, anyone?
I've been waiting for you. I want to show you something.
(reacts to the complexity) What is it?
The neuromuscular adaptation theory?

(excited at the prospects) It was a theory thirty years ago, Melora... but with the development of neo-analeptic transmitters during the last decade, it's not even that complicated... it's just that no one's gone back to reexamine the ideas of Nathaniel Teros... Until now.
This... can actually work... ?
No more servo controls. No more chair.
Have I done something wrong?
Not that I'm aware of. (Kot studies him evenly a beat) We have something in common.
We do?
I don't like Quark either. (beat, he looks up for the first time) But I can't let you kill him.
Kill him... did he tell you I was going to do that?
I know your history together.
Let bygones be bygones I always say.
I always say you can tell a man's intentions by the way he walks.
How do I walk?
Like someone carrying a lot of weight on his shoulders.
Must be the memory of those Romulan bricks I carried for eight years.
Must be.
But you can't lock a man up for the way he walks, can you?
Well?
I'd say he's a man with nothing to lose.
As opposed to me.
I have no reason to hold him for now and he knows it. I'll watch him the best I can.
But I suggest you carry a combadge with you at all times.
Call me at the first sign of trouble.
What if the first sign is the last sign?
You people sell pieces of yourself after you die, don't you?
Yes...
I'll buy one.
My heart is pounding...
I'd like to think that has more to do with me than the neo-analeptic infusion...
Would that also explain why my backside is getting warm...
That's more likely the result of the neuromuscular tissue stimulation due to increased activity in the motor cortex...
I'd say that's enough for the first time out...
It's good that you've already been using your muscles in this gravity environment... it'll make it easier to adapt...
Feel any different?
No.
Nothing at all?
I'm sorry, Julian.
The acetylcholine absorption was precisely at fourteen percent above normal...
... increased tensile strength would be the inevitable result...
Julian...
I can lift my leg.
Your neural pathways are getting used to the changes. Endurance and coordination might take awhile, but you should be walking within the hour.
and Dax at his station as Sisko walks out of his office towards them.
How's the upgrade coming?
We've been able to get it to about seventy percent of what we'd get with a standard EPS, but it looks like that's as far as it's gonna...
I'll be damned.
I wanted to give you our first day's mission summary myself, Commander.
A pleasure, Ensign.
Julian, how did you...
Simply a matter of increasing the output from the brain's motor cortex... someone else's research actually... I just dotted the "i"s and crossed the "t"s...
You'll get your name into the medical journals for this one.
I know.
Julian, I don't know how to say this but... I'm not sure I can get back down...
Whups! Easy does it now. First treatment's beginning to wear off. Nothing to be concerned about...
Let's get you back to your quarters... I want you to get a good night's rest.
With each progressive treatment, you should get stronger and the effect should last longer...
What about this?
A low-grav environment now would really confuse your motor cortex.
I understand. Julian...
You let me fly for the first time... I let you walk. We're even.
See you in the morning.
Lights...
Computer, turn on the...
Quark to mmmppph...
No one can hear you, Quark... it's just you and me...
Fallit... I wasn't prepared to entertain this evening but please... make yourself at home...
I already have...
What's mine is yours... all you have to do is ask... !
I'm tired of your gifts, Quark. All I want is your miserable life.

Wait! Everything's negotiable... believe me, I'm worth much more to you alive... ! (grabbing the first straw he thinks of) How does one hundred and ninety-nine bars of gold-pressed latinum sound to you?
It's a start.
The mattress felt like rocks... and every one of my muscles ached all night long...
You'll adjust to that after a few treatments...
This time you should feel the effects for several hours...
(tries to make it sound in passing) Exactly when does it become irreversible?
(studies her a long beat) Melora, if you're not certain...
Oh, I'm sure it's just some strange form of "buyers remorse"... I'll be fine...
Tell me exactly what you're feeling...
Last night, I just missed... I didn't feel like me...
If you want to end your dependence on the chair and the servo controls, you have to give up the low-grav environment, Melora. You knew that was the trade-off.
It seemed like a good trade... until I realized I couldn't do it anymore... if I could just spend...
I'm concerned that going back and forth would ultimately lead to a loss of fine motor control.
Meaning?
Your ability to perform complex tasks could be affected.
The effect is fully reversible for a few more days. We can pull the plug anytime before then. After that, if all goes well, your motor cortex impulses will kick in on their own. Permanently.
It's beginning to wear off again...

I don't understand myself... how can I possibly have second thoughts... this would mean real independence... it's everything I ever wished for... But then I start to think about home... and how I won't ever be able to go back... maybe just for a short visit... but never really go back...
The Little Mermaid.
Mermaid?
It's an Earth fable by Hans Christian Andersen. She trades her magical life under the sea for a pair of legs to walk on land.
What happened? Didn't she live happily ever after?
Ashrock... right on time... may I present my longtime business partner... Fallit Kot...
For your inspection.
Exquisite.
Then, our transaction is complete.
Not quite.
I'll be taking them too.
They warned me about you...
Not true. A deal is a deal. Rule of Acquisition number sixteen. Kot, you got what you came for... Now, let's be reasona...
(to Quark, re: the satchel) Pick it up. Move!
Priority one security to Level Twenty- two, Section Five.

Alarms still sounding. Kot and Quark come out of the Turbolift into the corridor, see two N.D. Security Personnel arriving... Kot fires several times, forcing them back... one Security Officer fires back, barely missing Quark and Kot... They take off in the opposite direction...
scene: 59   INT. DOCKING RING CORRIDOR OUTSIDE AIRLOCK

quote: I'm sure Julian would understand. Besides, he'd still get to publish the results of your first treatments...
Back into the ship.
Get us out of here.
He's already shot a man. Do as he says.
I'll just wait in the back...
In the front. Where I can see you. (to Melora, pointing out a seat) There. Hurry up.
I'm moving as fast as I can.
She's an Elaysian. She's needs motor support in our gravity.
They're in the Orinoco... the docking clamps have been released... thrusters engaged...
Ready a tractor beam. Open a channel.
Open.
This is Commander Benjamin Sisko. Return to the station at once.
No reply.
Engage tractor beam.
They've locked on to us with a tractor beam.
Open the channel to that Commander of yours.
Release this ship or I'll kill a hostage.
I'm willing to negotiate for your freedom... but first release those...
Didn't you hear what I just said?
No, I have something special in mind for you.
Do I make myself clear? Release the ship now!
Doctor, Chief... with me.
Beam us to the Rio Grande. Give us ten seconds and then disengage the tractor beam.
Understood. Energizing...
They've released us.
Through the wormhole.
What was that?
I'm not sure.
What was it?
Another ship coming through the wormhole.
Put it on the screen.
Take us to warp.
We haven't even set a course.
I don't care about the course... just go to warp...
If we don't set a course, we could warp ourselves into oblivion by crashing into a planet...
Fine. Set a course. Just get us out of here.
They're powering up their warp drive.
Stay with them.
Engaging warp engines.
Can we beam them aboard at warp... ?
I wouldn't recommend it.
Get the phasers ready.
I'm not going to fire at them.
You'll do it. Or you'll die.
Fine. Then I hope you can fly this ship.
Sit down!
Quark, how well do you know this man?
We've been friends for years. Not counting today.
I suggest you explain to him that Starfleet isn't going to give up and stop chasing us...
It's true, Fallit. You don't know these Starfleet types...
Then we'll all die.
Great. We escape, he's got something "special" planned for me. We don't escape, I just die with everyone else. Am I missing a choice, Fallit?
They've dropped out of warp...
Go to impulse...
Sir, their gravity generators are off...
Melora's alive.
Gravity's been reinstated... all engines are down...
Come on, Doctor...
I think we've got the situation in hand, Commander.
Sisko to Rio Grande. Everything's under control. We're going home.
Aye, Commander. Setting course for the wormhole.
Why didn't the phaser kill me... ?
I don't know. Maybe... all the neuro- stimulants we've been pumping into your system...
That's what I was wondering too...
It might turn out to be an interesting side effect of the treatment. It's worth exploring...
Julian, I'm not going ahead with the treatments.
You can always try it again someday if you change your mind.

I don't think I will. I like being independent. That's no secret. But to give up everything that I am to walk... ... on land... Well, I might be more independent but I wouldn't be Elaysian anymore. I'm not sure what I'd be. Besides, maybe independence isn't all it's cracked up to be. I kind of like how it feels to depend on someone for a change.
And I'm glad you got me to unlock the door to my quarters so I could finally let someone into my life.
So am I.
Aler acht'jar... Aler act'jar... T'lembda boool-gah toh-gal...
You must be exhausted... if you don't want to stay...
Let's just sit here awhile and listen... I want to remember all of this...
Aler acht'jar... Aler acht'jar... T'lembda boool-gah to lohhhh...
All right, Morn. You know the rules. No sleeping on the Promenade. Go home.
The risk is to you, Lieutenant.
I could probably think better without your hand on my thigh.
Now, how did that get there?
So what's it gonna be? Confront? Evade? Acquire? Retreat?
Confront.
Yes.
Doesn't she ever lose?
(gazing with admiration at Dax) Tell me, Lieutenant, how did you get to be so good at tongo?
Actually, Curzon used to play it all the time.
Well, that explains it. It's Curzon who's beating us, not this female.
This female happens to be a better player than Curzon ever was.
And a prettier one too.
Maybe so. But I still prefer a Ferengi female. One who never wears clothes, never talks back, and never plays tongo.
Is that how you really prefer your women? Naked and submissive.
Do you find such a lifestyle appealing?
Don't you wish.
Oh I do. I really do.
All right everyone. The opening risk is five strips of latinum. The purchase is at three. The sell at eight.
No, absolutely not. This isn't the proper time.
I'm trying to concentrate.
I'm sorry, Brother. It's this insolent young waiter's fault.
My apologies, Quark. But I really think you should try this.
What is it?
A way to double your beverage profits. Taste it.
You see. Just as I told you. He immediately reached for his drink.
So I did.
Amazing. You don't even realize you're thirsty. What are they?

Gramilian Sand Peas. They inhibit secretion of the salivary glands while drying out the tissues of the tongue. Works every time. You replace your complimentary dishes of lokar beans with sand peas and you won't be able to fill your customers' glasses fast enough.
What's your name again?
Pel... so what do you think about my idea?
I think I agree with the fifty-ninth Rule of Acquisition, "Free advice is seldom cheap."
True, but the twenty-second rule says, "A wise man can hear profit in the wind."
I see you know your Rules.
All two hundred and eighty-five of them. And the various commentaries as well. I don't plan on being a waiter forever.
Good. Then you're fired.
Shut up, Rom. When it comes to business, my brother has the weak little lobes of a female. So what made you take a job here at the station?
I wanted to learn from the best.
Which brings to mind the thirty-third Rule of Acquisition...
"It never hurts to suck up to the boss."
What's that?
It's Grand Nagus Zek's personal subspace frequency.
I wonder what he wants.
Why do you look so surprised? I told you I'd be back.
I've looked forward to your return, Nagus.
Still the perfect little toady, eh, Quark?
I try to be.
Then listen carefully. The Ferengi expansion into the Gamma Quadrant is about to begin. I'd like you to be my chief negotiator.
Me?
That's right. I'm offering you an opportunity to make more profit than you ever dreamed of. All you have to do is earn it.
Can I interest anyone in some Hupyrian beetle snuff?
I don't think so.
Major?
No, thank you.
Suit yourself... more for me.
(grabs it out of his hand) A little late, aren't we?
So, you wanted to see me, Commander?
I understand that you're planning to host a business conference here at the station.
With the Dosi, a race from the Gamma Quadrant. A very profitable opportunity for all concerned, I might add.
Profitable for the Ferengi, maybe.
Are you implying something, Major?
Me? Not at all. The Ferengi's reputation speaks for itself.
A reputation of honesty, decency, and reliability. You always know what to expect when you do business with the Ferengi.
Which is why, if you're smart, you don't do business with the Ferengi...
I think you've made your point, Major.
As misinformed and misguided as it may be. Besides, how we do business is none of your concern.
Except when you conduct your business on this station.

In other words, Zek, Grand Nagus or no Grand Nagus, if we allow you to hold these negotiations here, and we find out you're cheating these Dosi, I'll see to it that you never set foot on this station again.
Did anyone ever tell you your eyes shine with the brilliance of Kibberian fire diamonds.
Not that I recall.
Well they do.
Tell me, Major, could Bajor use fifty thousand kilos of Brizeen nitrate?
Of course we could. With that much Brizeen, we could fertilize the entire northern peninsula.
Well I've recently come into possession of fifty thousand kilos of Brizeen nitrate. And to show you how much your cooperation means to me, I'll let you have the entire shipment.
I'll still need your assurances that the Dosi will be treated fairly while they're here.
You have my word. Then it's settled. Let's see, that's fifty thousand kilos at... twenty-five percent off our usual price.
Twenty-five percent? You just said you were giving it to them.
You're right, Commander. We're all friends here. I'll let you have it at cost.
I have a better idea. Why not consider the nitrate a gift to the people of Bajor.
A gift. That doesn't sound very profitable.
That depends.
On what?
On whether you want to conduct business here or not.
Your negotiation skills aren't bad... for a human.
Your nitrate will be delivered promptly. Anything else you need, please come see me personally.
You know Quark, I've been involved in some profitable opportunities in my time. But my lobes are telling me this may be the most profitable opportunity in Ferengi history.
Imagine that. And part of those profits will be mine.
Profit. Fame. Power. As much as you want.
Tell me, Nagus, what exactly is this great opportunity.
I can sum it up in one word... tulaberries.
(not what he expected to hear) Tulaberries?
Exactly.
Go on.
They're the main ingredient in tulaberry wine. Your job is to purchase ten thousand vats from the Dosi.
We're going into the wine business?
Within a year we'll have made tulaberry wine the most popular drink in their entire sector.
That's enough.
Yes, I like it. Very distinguished.
Tell me, Nagus, how are tulaberries going to be the most profitable opportunity in Ferengi history?
Do I have to spell it out for you?
If you don't mind...
The tulaberries establish a Ferengi presence inside the Gamma Quadrant. And once we get our foot in the door, they'll never get it out.
Yes, I see...
(with a conspiratorial smile) Tulaberries, Quark. Tulaberries.
Tulaberries? I wonder what they taste like?
Who cares what they taste like. They're an opportunity to get a Ferengi foot in the Gamma Quadrant door.
And it'll be your foot, brother. I'm so proud.
I'm going to make history, Rom. And I'm going to be rich. And I have the Grand Nagus to thank for it. He must really like me.
Just remember one thing, "The bigger the smile, the sharper the knife."
The forty-eighth Rule of Acquisition.
I'd keep it in mind if I were you.
He has some nerve.
